WRITING.TEXT:
It wasn't removed. It was blocked by a Content ID claim. Something the original-uploader can dispute via a risk-free process in less than 30 seconds... and instantly have his video and monetization restored.
It's an overlap with assets within the CMS database. It happens all the time, and is hardly newsworthy. Let alone emblematic of YouTube's "current state", whatever the hell that means.

WRITING.TITLE: It's always, "Cardassia IV", "Veridian III", "Norpin V" etc. - Seems like there's never any planets with the destination "I".
WRITING.TEXT: I'm sure they must exist in canon somewhere, and a quick glance at a Wikipedia list confirms this - but does it bother anyone else that 95% of all planets mentioned on the shows are rarely just "1"? A stupid, minor gripe - but a bit of a pet peeve I wanted to share :)

I went in 2012 in Indianapolis. That shit was locked down tighter than a camel's ass in a sandstorm. Tickets/badges are required to be visible whenever you're moving around, there's multiple check-points and metal-detectors, and every fifth person is security.
I won't say it's impossible - but you'd need to do a lot of reconnaissance work for a venue that isn't really set-up until the week of. Maybe try a regular season game first?

Do you think that could change with better moderation?
Honestly, who knows? Never quite understood what makes certain SubReddits succeed where others fail. I do like the idea of a view/sub requirement though; would weed out a LOT of the elementary questions / threads.
/r/LetsPlay is (usually) an excellent community/sub though - genre-specific, but covers a lot of basic YouTube stuff better than most YouTube-related groups. Like here though, you get new users asking dumb questions, and others outright refuting /ignoring the proven advice from larger guys like myself. Which can be frustrating.

Huh? No. Did you just make that shit up? There's no "account holding party" - it's just Google Adsense. The third-party that's already responsible for all the money on the site to begin with. They simply don't pay either party until it's resolved. This doesn't "encourage" anything.

it will take at least a few hours for Google/Youtube to get back to us.

I was just making extremely comfortable earnings on AdSense alone - and diversified across hundreds (now thousands) of evergreen videos. Besides, in 2008, etc, there weren't many other ways to earn money. Merchandise has never sold particularly well, and sponsorships just weren't negotiated regularly enough to be dependable. But, still, I've made tens of thousands on non-YouTube sources, it just wasn't a consistent thing I focused on until the past couple years.
And yes, RPM rates used to be about 4x what they are now, at least for my channels.

#Don't join a network.
As soon as YouTube introduced the Partner Program in 2008. Why would you wait?

Was one of the first channels invited into the "Partnership" back in February of 2008 with only 2,000 subs or so. Was able to go full-time 15 months later with around 80,000 subscribers. Wasn't really a "decision" though - my existing job ended suddenly, and I was forced to make YouTube work.
Relied entirely on AdSense for income for the next six years. Only recently began branching out to other revenue streams.

Just that, generally speaking - they're much slower than their secondary-playing counterparts, and the Jets defense should have been better positioned to stop them. Bruschi's incredible accomplishments notwithstanding.

Even as a Patriots fan I feel bad for New York... almost :-)
